title-group.article-title: Gender Differences in Personal Selling Ethics Evaluations
title-group.subtitle: Do They Exist and What Does Their Existence Mean for Teaching Sales Ethics?

abstract.p: Sales career opportunities are growing, and the number of women in sales is increasing. Educators must adequately prepare both men and women for today’s ethical sales dilemmas. Using the Personal Selling Ethics Scale, the current study analyzes the impact of idealism and relativism on the sales ethics evaluations of men and women. Results indicate that women evaluate sales ethics scenarios as less ethical than males and that varying positions on these ethical frameworks partially explain the divergence. Results also imply that today’s sales educators should primarily emphasize moral idealism when teaching sales ethics. Ethical codes and situation-based frameworks can aid this effort. When teaching relativistic individuals, educators can supplement idealistic methods via the use of cognitive moral development frameworks.

body.p: Sales career opportunities are growing at a 9% rate through 2016, and the number of women in sales and related occupations is nearing the 50% mark (Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2010). However, positive impressions of sales have not kept pace with the growth, and sales is widely considered to be a prime arena for ethical abuse (Luthy, 2007; Ramsey, Marshall, Johnston, & Deeter-Schmelz, 2007). Although females are generally found to be more sensitive to ethical issues in business and sales (Dawson, 1992, 1997), there is little recent research reviewing the relative ethical sensitivities of males and females in sales situations (O’Fallon & Butterfield, 2005). Since women are now heavily represented within sales, an understanding of the manner in which each gender evaluates personal selling ethics is required. The current study seeks to further this understanding by analyzing gender responses to ethical sales situations and by suggesting possible reasons behind the differences. Findings may be useful for the preparation of pedagogical methods and ethical codes within academia and industry.

The article begins by reviewing past research on gender-specific ethical evaluations. Particular attention is paid to idealism and relativism since the two constructs are hypothesized to influence the manner in which individuals respond to ethics scenarios in marketing (Singhapakdi, 2004). Next, male and female responses to various ethical situations in sales are tested. Results are compared with results from Forsyth’s (1980) moral relativism/idealism test to help uncover possible reasons behind the gender divide. The article concludes with pedagogical recommendations.

sec.title: Literature Review and Hypotheses
sec.p: Two streams of associated research must inform a review of gender and ethical evaluations. The first addresses the manner in which gender influences ethical evaluations, and the second addresses the manner in which preexisting moral frameworks influence ethical evaluations. The latter offers a means to determine possible factors behind the hypothesized gender divide. The present section offers the research context for each stream.

sec.title: Gender and Ethical Evaluations
sec.p: During the 1960s and 1970s, feminist research generally sought to minimize the notion of gender differences (Grant, 1988). By the 1980s the effort had largely failed and was replaced by a research stream, continuing to the present day, that recognizes both the divergence and complementarity of the sexes (Pool, 1994; Smith & Rogers, 2000). The current section reviews gender research related to general ethical evaluations.

Despite the fact that both genders view their ethical standards as higher than the other (Kidwell, Stevens, & Bethke, 1987), research over the past generation has indicated that the ethical evaluations of men are often less sensitive than those of women (Beu, Buckley, & Harvey, 2003; Dobson & White, 1995; Gilligan, 1982). Some researchers disagree with the notion of an ethical gender divide (Sikula & Costa, 1994; Walker, 1984), but Collin’s (2000) survey of 47 studies in the Journal of Business Ethics revealed that few empirical analyses of gender and ethics conclusively confirmed that a divergence does not exist. O’Fallon and Butterfield’s (2005) review of 49 articles moderated Collin’s consensus through uncovering that almost half of the articles (23 studies) showed few differences between male and female ethical evaluations. However, the remaining 26 studies indicated that, in most situations, women are more ethically sensitive. Ford and Richardson’s (1994) review of 14 studies on ethical values indicated that one-half found a difference, and the other half found no difference. Weeks, Moore, McKinney, and Longenecker (1999) found similar inconsistencies across studies. However, among the studies finding a difference, women uniformly emerged as evaluating ethical situations more stringently. Less ethically sensitive male evaluations were seen across a spectrum of issues ranging from broad social issues to double standards to sexual exploitation (Smith & Oakley, 1997; Vermeir & Van Kenhove, 2008). Therefore, women are more likely to view ethical misconduct unfavorably, especially in business settings (Franke, Crown, & Spake, 1997). This suggestion particularly holds true during the early years of a person’s career.

Explanations for the apparent divide vary. Trait-driven approaches seek to explain the divergence by reviewing the generalized traits of male instrumentalism versus female sensitivity, emotional understanding, and moderated competitiveness (Grimshaw, 1993; Hunt, 1997; Weeks et al., 1999). Innately different biological roots have also been considered to be the primary driver behind differing ethical evaluations (Pool, 1994).

Alternate explanations use gender socialization theory to suggest that differing ethical evaluations primarily stem from divergent socialization processes. Gender socialization theory traces its foundations to Freud (1925) and Piaget (1932) and suggests that varying socialization methods, rather than innate biological differences, primarily account for differences between male and female orientations (Lever, 1978). Gilligan’s (1982) pioneering research applied gender socialization theory to ethical evaluations and suggested divergent patterns were related to unique socialization experiences. Men are generally rewarded for succeeding through competition and women are generally rewarded for exhibiting nurturing behaviors (Kohlberg, 1984; Roxas & Stoneback, 2004). Therefore, gender socialization theory suggests that since the cutting of ethical corners is usually more tempting in competitive versus nurturing situations, males can be expected to exhibit less sensitive ethical evaluations.

In sales, Dabholkar and Kellaris’s (1992) Personal Selling Ethics Scale (PSE) has been used to test gender evaluation differences. The PSE presents a range of ethical situations in sales and requests users to rate the degree to which they feel the situation is or is not ethical. Four of the sales ethics scenarios in the original PSE revealed statistically significant gender differences. Subsequent studies have encountered evaluation differences across a wide array of PSE scenarios (Donoho et al., 1998; Donoho, Herche, & Swenson, 2003). The current study uses an updated version of the PSE, referred to as the Personal Selling Ethics Scale–2 (PSE-2; Donoho & Heinze, 2011). The PSE-2 is reproduced in the appendix and is used to test the following sales ethics evaluation hypothesis:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1: Females will evaluate sales ethics dilemma scenarios as less ethical than males.

sec.title: Moral Frameworks–Moral Idealism Versus Relativism
sec.p: The philosophical frameworks that guide actions are important, offering the basis for a nuanced understanding of ethical gender variations (Schminke, 1997). The current section highlights the reasoning behind this study’s utilization of an idealism/relativism framework and then offers a review of that framework.

Hunt and Vitell’s (1986) general theory of marketing ethics has enjoyed widespread use within marketing and sales (see McClaren, 2000) and provides an umbrella framework for the study of ethical evaluations within specific sales situations. The model suggests that an individual’s perception of ethical problems and alternatives is influenced by various background factors such as, among others, normative moral philosophies. Forsyth’s (1980, 1992) pioneering work on moral philosophies resulted in the development of the Ethics Position Questionnaire (EPQ). Underlying and fundamental to the EPQ were the notions of moral idealism and relativism. Schlenker and Forsyth (1977) argued that idealism and relativism were two foundational dimensions of personal moral philosophies, and the two constructs went on to provide a descriptive scale for reviewing moral philosophies such as situationalism, absolutism, subjectivism, and exceptionalism.

Based on a set of universal absolutes, moral idealism judges actions as moral or immoral, while also contending that it is possible to avoid harming others (Forsyth, 1992). Conversely, individuals who are less idealistic are willing to settle for the “lesser of two evils” in order to accomplish some supposed good (Forsyth, 1980).

In contrast to idealism, moral relativism asserts that universal absolutes should not inform ethical judgments. Rather, situational factors and participant variables should drive moral decisions (Forsyth, 1992). Individual characteristics and circumstantial factors trump rules. Singhapakdi (2004) additionally points out that culture and society may be a broad circumstantial factor that influences relativists.

Though not specifically used to evaluate scenarios within the personal selling process, Forsyth’s (1980) categorizations and their underlying dimensions (idealism and relativism) have been used in many sales studies, and Stead, Worrell, and Stead (1990) proposed that idealism and relativism should be universally added to ethical models. McClaren’s (2000) review of sales ethics research demonstrates that a sales manager’s ability to develop and train subordinates is aided by understanding the divergent moral ideologies of salespeople. However, divergent ideological orientations do not explain all variations in ethical evaluation. Sivadas, Kleiser, Kellaris, and Dahlstrom (2003) found that although moral relativism did influence sales managers’ opinions of ethical situations, moral idealism had no effect. Likewise, Singhapakdi (2004) illustrated that moral idealism had no effect on ethical intentions, whereas relativism shared a reverse relationship with ethical intentions. The study uncovered that marketing students who held higher relativistic perspectives were less likely to demonstrate positive ethical intentions.

Nevertheless, an array of studies supports the contention that both relativism and idealism affect ethical intentions and actions. Vitell and Singhapakdi (1993) demonstrated that idealistic marketers exhibited higher ethical judgments and were less likely to act dishonestly. Additionally, Bass, Barnett, and Brown (1999) found that idealists were more inclined to judge questionable selling practices as unethical. Valentine and Bateman (2011) determined that, along with issue contingencies and environmental constructs, ethical ideologies influenced ethical issue recognition and intentions. In particular, idealistic individuals were found to be more sensitive and relativistic individuals were found to be less sensitive to ethical misconduct in sales. Therefore, as background factors within Hunt and Vitell’s (1986) model, idealism and relativism represent individual differences that can influence both the manner and method of ethical judgments (Barnett, Bass, & Brown, 1994; Tansey, Brown, Hyman, & Dawson, 1994).

Gender research regarding ethical philosophies is surprisingly scarce. Although numerous studies over the past 20 years have reviewed gender evaluation differences in business ethics (Franke et al., 1997; Gaedeke, Kelley, & Tootelian, 1992; Malinowski & Berger, 1996; Peterson, Beltramini, & Kozmetsky, 1991; Ruegger & King, 1992; Whipple & Wolf, 1991), few have specifically reviewed gender differences in terms of normative moral philosophies. Schminke (1997) offered an exception by finding that ethical frameworks are fairly consistent across genders, with both males and females leaning toward relativism. Further refinement of the study illustrated that slight differences can be teased out. In business settings, women more strongly favored Kant’s categorical imperative (Schminke & Ambrose, 1997). However, in nonbusiness settings, women preferred an idealistic approach (the Golden Rule) whereas men leaned toward a relativistic framework.

Loe and Weeks (2000) touched on moral philosophies by uncovering that females use higher levels of moral reasoning than males. Singhapakdi and Vitell’s (1994) review of American Marketing Association collegiate chapters indicated that male marketing students were less idealistic and less relativistic than females. Subsequent research indicated that the intentions of female marketing students were more ethical than the intentions of male students (Singhapakdi, 2004).

Therefore, despite their limitations, idealism and relativism should still be considered when reviewing sales ethics since they inform ethical actions in a fairly consistent manner across the genders (Schminke, 1997). In light of the general findings associated with gender, moral frameworks, and ethical evaluations, the following hypotheses are proposed:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2: Females will score higher on moral idealism than males.
Hypothesis 3: Males will score higher on moral relativism than females.
Hypothesis 4: Sales ethics evaluations are negatively related to moral idealism. Students higher in moral idealism are less tolerant of sales ethical dilemmas.
Hypothesis 5: Sales ethics evaluations are positively related to moral relativism. Students higher in moral relativism are more tolerant of sales ethical dilemmas.
Hypothesis 6: Sales ethics evaluations will not be affected by gender differences when moral idealism and moral relativism are taken into account (gender differences will not be significant).

sec.title: Method
sec.p: To test the philosophical frameworks in sales-specific situations, two questionnaires were used. First, an updated version of Dabholkar and Kellaris’s (1992) PSE was used to test whether an ethical gender divide exists in sales situations. The new scale is referred to as PSE-2 (Donoho & Heinze, 2011). Second, a modified version of Forsyth’s (1980) EPQ was used to test whether idealism and relativism may influence gender evaluation differences.

sec.title: Data Collection and Sample Characteristics
sec.p: Study data were collected as part of a larger multisemester, multisurvey questionnaire administered to over 1000 students in marketing classes at a public university in the West. The first questionnaire included the PSE-2 (Donoho & Heinze, 2011) and an array of demographic questions. The PSE-2 (see the appendix) is composed of 20 ethical sales situations which participants evaluate using a 7-point semantic differential scale (1 = very unethical, 7 = very ethical). A subsequent survey of a smaller subset of students included Forsyth’s (1980) EPQ moral idealism and relativism scales (5-point Likert-type scale with 1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree). The surveys were administered via an online survey tool. Taking an average total time of 20 minutes to complete, the survey items for the current study were completed by 429 students who received course credit. Table 1 presents sample characteristics by gender. Males represented 57% of the sample. Although demographically similar in all other respects, females were slightly younger than males.

sec.title: Scale Characteristics
sec.p: The PSE and EPQ (moral idealism and moral relativism) scales are presented in Tables 2, 3, and 4. Reliability assessment using Cronbach’s alpha was .79 for the PSE2. There was a relatively wide range of mean scores (1 = very unethical, 7 = very ethical) for the 20 PSE-2 items, ranging from “stealing from competitor at trade show” (males, 1.84; females, 1.84) to “puffery” (males, 5.10; females, 5.22). The standard deviations for the mean scores were smaller for sales scenarios evaluated as less ethical and increased for scenarios evaluated as more ethical. This is supported by regression results of mean ethical evaluation by standard deviation (males, adjusted R2 = .458, p = .001, standardized Beta coefficient = .698; females, adjusted R2 = .504, p = .000, standardized Beta coefficient = .728).

Cronbach’s alpha for the EPQ was .82 for moral idealism, and .71 for moral relativism. These values are consistent with previous use of these scales and are considered adequate (Nunnally, 1978). A wide array of studies have used the EPQ (or associated variations) and have experienced similar results. Reported reliabilities for moral idealism and relativism have included the following: Singhapadki (2004), .87 and .79; Kleiser, Sivadas, Kellaris, and Dahlstrom (2003), .81 and .70; Valentine and Bateman (2011), .84 and .81; and Bass, Barnett, and Brown (1998), .86 and .81.

A factor analysis constraining the EPQ scale items to two factors resulted in appropriate loadings that matched the idealism and relativism constructs. Factor loadings varied from .41 to .78 for moral idealism and .49 to.63 for moral relativism, except for idealism scale item 7 (.268) and relativism scale item 1 (.377). Deletion of these items from the analysis did not significantly improve Cronbach’s alpha scores. Therefore, the scales were used in their complete form.

The mean score for the PSE-2 (males, 3.40; females, 3.29) fell between neither unethical nor ethical and somewhat unethical, using a 7-point Likert-type scale. Mean scores for moral idealism (males, 3.46; females, 3.63) and moral relativism (males, 3.21; females, 3.15) fell between neither disagree nor agree and agree, using a 5-point Likert-type scale.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Hypothesis 1 was supported. There are gender differences in the PSE-2 Scale. Table 2 presents the results. A multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) of the 20 PSE-2 scale items by gender was conducted, resulting in significant gender differences (Wilks’s Λ = 2.408, p < .001). Individual analyses of variance (ANOVAs) revealed that five scale items (inflating expense report, offering a monetary bribe to buyer, charging customers different prices, sneaking vacations on company time, and cheating on the bidding process) were responsible for the rejection. All five items were in the hypothesized direction, being viewed as less ethical by females (p < .05) than by males. In all, 14 of the 20 PSE-2 scale items were in the hypothesized direction. The mean for all 20 PSE-2 items was significantly lower for females than for males (F = 3.83, p < .003).

sec.p: Hypothesis 2 was likewise supported. Females scored higher on moral idealism than males. Table 3 presents the relationship between gender and moral idealism. Overall, females have higher scores on moral idealism than males (MANOVA Wilks’s Λ F = 3.338, p = .001, idealism mean ANOVA F = 8.502, p = .004). Six of the 10 idealism scale items were significantly higher for females.

caption.p: Mean Idealism by Gender (1 = Strongly Disagree, 5 = Strongly Agree)

tr.td: Idealism 1: A person should make certain that their actions never intentionally harm another even to a small degree.
Idealism 2: Risks to another should never be tolerated, irrespective of how small the risks might be.
Idealism 3: The existence of potential harm to others is always wrong, irrespective of the benefits to be gained.
Idealism 4: One should never psychologically or physically harm another person.
Idealism 5: One should not perform an action that might in any way threaten the dignity and welfare of another individual.
Idealsim 6: If an action could harm an innocent other, then it should not be done.
Idealism 7: Deciding whether or not to perform an act by balancing the positive consequences of the act against the negative consequences of the act is immoral.
Idealism 8: The dignity and welfare of people should be the most important concern in any society.
Idealism 9: It is never necessary to sacrifice the welfare of others.
Idealism 10: Moral actions are those which closely match ideals of the most “perfect” action.

sec.p: Generating significant MANOVA results, Hypothesis 3 was partially supported. Table 4 presents the relationship between gender and moral relativism. The MANOVA for all 10 scale items was significant (Wilks’s Λ F = 2.349, p < .010). Rejection of the hypothesis was driven by only 2 of the 10 relativism scale items. Males scored higher on moral relativism for both items. However, there was not a significant difference between males and females for the overall relativism mean of the scale items (ANOVA F = 1.321, p = .251).

caption.p: Mean Relativism by Gender (1 = Strongly Disagree, 5 = Strongly Agree)

tr.td: Relativism 1: There are no ethical principles that are so important that they should be a part of any code of ethics.
Relativism 2: What is ethical varies from one situation and society to another.
Relativism 3: Moral standards should be seen as being individualistic; what one person considers to be moral may be judged to be immoral by another person.
Relativism 4: Different types of moralities cannot be compared as to “rightness.”
Relativism 5: What is ethical for everyone can never be resolved since what is moral or immoral is up to the individual.
Relativism 6: Moral standards are simple personal rules which indicate how a person should behave, and are not to be applied in making judgments of others.
Relativism 7: Ethical considerations in interpersonal relations are so complex that individuals should be allowed to formulate their own individual codes.
Relativism 8: Rigidly codifying an ethical option that prevents certain types of actions could stand in the way of better human relations and adjustment.
Relativism 9: No rule concerning lying can be formulated; whether a lie is permissible or not permissible totally depends on the situation.
Relativism 10: Whether a lie is judged to be moral or immoral depends on the circumstances surround the action.

sec.p: A regression analysis was used to test Hypotheses 4 to 6. Table 5 presents the results. The mean PSE-2 response was the dependent variable, and the mean moral idealism and relativism responses were the independent variables. Three regressions were run: one for males, one for females, and one for the combined sample. All three regressions were significant.

caption.p: Regression Analysis: Personal Selling Ethics Scale–2 Mean by Idealism Mean, Relativism Mean, and Gender

sec.p: For males, mean moral idealism was negatively related to mean PSE-2 (standardized Beta coefficient = −.192), supporting Hypothesis 4. Mean moral relativism was positively related to mean PSE-2 (standardized Beta coefficient = +.253), supporting Hypothesis 5. This analysis also holds for the total sample (mean idealism standardized Beta coefficient = −.200; mean relativism standardized Beta coefficient = +.222).

For females, both Hypothesis 4 and Hypothesis 5 were supported. Moral idealism was negatively related to PSE-2 and to mean idealism (standardized Beta coefficient = −194; mean relativism standardized Beta coefficient = +.170). With respect to sales ethics evaluations, males and females had similar mean moral idealism standardized Beta coefficients, whereas males had higher mean relativism standardized Beta coefficients.

Table 6 presents the results of an ANOVA of mean PSE-2 by gender with mean idealism and mean relativism as covariates. Mean idealism and mean relativism were significant (F = 16.638, p = .000; F = 21.927, p = .000) and gender was not significant (F = 1.390, p = .239). In other words, the gender effect in sales ethical evaluations disappears when idealism and relativism are taken into consideration. However, the effect of idealism and relativism explains less than 9% of the variance in sales ethics evaluations. This analysis supports Hypotheses 4, 5, and 6.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The current study’s results partially explain the mixed results associated with prior gender research. Although the current study uncovered gender differences in the evaluation of sales ethics scenarios, these differences were not significant when moral idealism and relativism positions were taken into account. Therefore, gender differences in sales ethics evaluations are partially the result of ethical position differences. Though both men and women weigh moral idealism similarly, men are more prone to hold relativistic positions. This positional variance results in lower, less sensitive sales ethics evaluations on the part of males. Though findings confirm the relevance of background factors within (idealism and relativism) Hunt & Vitell’s (1986) model, idealism and relativism do not entirely explain the differences in sales ethics evaluations. Additional causal constructs are present, and the uncovering of these constructs represents an opportunity for future research.

sec.title: Implications for Sales Ethics Training
sec.p: The study’s first implication extends beyond gender and points to the critical importance of vigorously including ethical training within today’s sales and marketing classes. The current study’s overall mean PSE-2 score (males, 3.40; females, 3.29) indicates that students do not view today’s sales dilemmas in an ethically sensitive manner. All PSE-2 scenarios involve lying, misrepresentation, or withholding information for the purposes of benefiting the sales representative at another party’s expense. However, when asked to rate the degree to which the described action/scenario was unethical, students replied with an average response that falls between “somewhat unethical” and “neither unethical nor ethical.” Given this average response, it can be assumed that a large percentage of respondents might behave in an ethically problematic manner when confronted by ethical sales dilemmas.

The study’s second implication is that morally idealistic frameworks should be used to effectively teach ethics in the sales profession. Regardless of gender, individuals who subscribe to an idealistic moral framework generally demonstrate increased sensitivity to ethical issues. Therefore, as suggested by Singhapakdi (2004), teaching and encouraging morally idealistic perspectives may increase the likelihood that students will pursue ethical alternatives when faced with questionable sales scenarios. Incorporating moral idealism tools within the classroom may include using codes of ethics or practical representations of these codes such as the PSE-2 (Donoho & Heinze, 2011). Reviewing the individual items of the PSE-2 provides a relatively comprehensive overview of the dilemmas covered by sales codes or encountered in the sales process. The situations within the PSE-2 could be used as a codified framework for discussing these dilemmas, or as the basis for research, role-plays, and assessments regarding the dilemmas.

Finally, the large number of students (especially men) who hold relativistic ethical frameworks suggests the inclusion (alongside idealistic approaches) of utilitarian arguments for ethical behavior. The PSE-2 includes items that are problematic for students holding a utilitarian perspective (e.g., anticipated negative consequences from the situation is clear and would result from the action), and these situations could be used to emphasize the negative utility associated with unethical sales actions.

Another recommended approach for instructing relativists is based on cognitive moral development. Ferrell and Gresham (1985) discussed the framework, Wortruba (1990) developed an ethical decision-making process, and Loe and Weeks (2000) confirmed its effectiveness. The Wortruba (1990) approach is as follows:

list-item.p: Recognize what actions are possible in a given situation, what the outcomes would be, and who would be affected by each alternative outcome (possible consequences);
Determine which alternative is morally right and therefore represents what one ought to do in that situation from an ethical perspective (moral idealism);
Assign priority to ethical and moral values relative to other values (relativism; such as economic), producing the intention to do what is ethically right; and
Convert the intention into action—an ethical decision or behavior.

sec.p: Therefore, it is recommended that although educators should primarily emphasize idealistic perspectives, utilitarian appeals should also be used when dealing with relativistic students.

sec.title: Future Research and Limitations
sec.p: Since moral idealism and relativism explain a relatively small portion of the variance in PSE-2 scores, other constructs should also be considered. As suggested by Hunt and Vitell (1986), ethical evaluations are antecedent to decision making in a macro marketing ethics model. A complete model also reviews intentions and behaviors, and these constructs could be tested via an experimental methodology in which scenarios are manipulated based on the degree of unethical behavior and the anticipated consequences of that behavior.

Evaluating sales managers and trainers is also recommended since their focused leadership efforts, via the institutionalization of ethical standards, can minimize ethical breaches (Ingram, LaForge, & Schwepker, 2007; Singhapakdi & Vitell, 2007). Evaluating sales managers, corporate trainers, and academic instructors could help determine whether the personal moral frameworks of managers or educators influence their pedagogical methods. Future research should also examine the manner in which sales educators view sales ethics evaluations, and attention should be paid to the methods they use to instill ethical sensitivity in sales situations.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Given the growth in sales career opportunities and the number of women pursuing those opportunities, educators must adequately prepare both men and women for facing today’s ethical sales dilemmas. The current study tested the effect that idealism and relativism have on the manner in which each gender evaluates ethical situations in sales. Results indicate that men and women vary in their evaluations of sales ethics scenarios, and that the ethical frameworks used to guide decision making influence these evaluations. Idealistic and relativistic frameworks were examined, and although men and women weight moral idealism similarly, men are more prone to hold relativistic ethical frameworks. When these ethical frameworks are taken into consideration, the gender effect disappears. Therefore, gender evaluation differences can be partially explained by differences in ethical frameworks. Future research should examine additional causal factors.

Study implications include the suggestion that today’s sales educators should primarily emphasize moral idealism. Ethical codes and situation-based frameworks such as the PSE-2 can help educators in this effort. When teaching relativistic individuals, educators can supplement idealistic methods with the use of cognitive moral development frameworks.

sec.title: Personal Selling Ethics Scale–2 Ethical Scenarios (Items)

list-item.p: Bribes and gifts: Monetary bribe to buyer

sec.p: A wine wholesale distributor was running a special contest for its salespeople. Salesperson X was only 10 cases away from selling enough to win a $500 bonus. The customer was pressed to place a 10th case order. When the buyer voiced reluctance, X told the buyer about the sales contest and offered to “split” the bonus to “help make the quota.”

list-item.p: 2. Sabotage and spying: Steal from competitor

sec.p: While attending a trade show, Salesperson Y passed by a competitor’s exhibit that was temporarily unattended. Y took all of the free product samples from the competitor’s booth. Y felt that this not exactly “stealing” because the samples were there to be taken for free anyway. “Besides,” Y thought, “if they’re stupid enough to leave their exhibit unattended. . . .” When the competitor returned it was discovered that the product samples were missing and no more were available for prospective buyers attending the trade show.

list-item.p: 3. Expense accounts: Inflate expense report

sec.p: W is basically an honest hard-working salesperson. However, W occasionally “inflates” the expense report, rationalizing that this would cover any expense W had overlooked. This is common practice in W’s company and is ignored by the sales manager.

list-item.p: 4. Misusing company time: Sneak vacations on company time

sec.p: When Salesperson V gets a hotel room and rents a car to make out-of-town calls, V sometimes keeps the room and the car an extra day or two for personal use. This allows V to sneak in “mini vacations” without taking time off. This is common practice in the company and V feels that the relaxation makes for a more effective employee for the company. V has always been a top 10% performer in his company’s sales force.

list-item.p: 5. Conflicts of interest: Moonlighting

sec.p: Salesperson M is a former computer programmer who now sells computer hardware for XYZ Company. In M’s spare time, M developed some software that M sells “on the side.” Most of the buyers of M’s software are company’s customers that M contacted through the job. The company also sells software to run on its equipment. M sees no problem with this situation because M feels it’s up to the customer to decide which product is best for them.

list-item.p: 6. Entertainment: Lavish entertaining

sec.p: Salespeople at Manufacturer ABC often spend large amounts of money on entertaining clients and prospective clients. It is not unusual for a salesperson at A to invite a client and their spouse to an expensive ($500) dinner. The client’s company has a policy against accepting gifts, but, as the salesperson at ABC likes to say, “everybody’s got to eat. . . .”

list-item.p: 7. Taking advantage: Cheating on sales contest

sec.p: The D Company sometimes holds sales contests for its sales force. The salesperson with the most sales during the contest period (usually one month) would win a cash bonus. Salesperson V found an easy way to “boost sales” during the contest. V simply held the orders from previous weeks and did not turn them in until after the contest period began. To this V added regular orders taken during the contest period.

list-item.p: 8. Overpromising and passing blame: False promises used to close sale

sec.p: Salesperson R was young, inexperienced, and eager to make a sale. To close a sale, R promised a customer a delivery time that R knew the company probably could not meet. R thought, “if the customer complains about the order arriving late, I’ll just blame it on the shipping department.”

list-item.p: 9. Misusing confidential information: Cheating on the bidding process

sec.p: Salesperson S would sometimes ask customers for information about the competitors’ prices. This frequently enabled S to underprice the competition when bidding for the job.

list-item.p: 10. Manipulation: Fear appeal to close sale

sec.p: Psychological research has revealed that irrational social anxiety and a fear of growing old are primary motives underlying consumer’s use of a certain group of products. A door-to-door salesperson for a company that markets such products has used this information to increase sales dramatically. “It’s easy to sell [our products] if you just work on [the prospect’s] natural fears.”

list-item.p: 11. Misusing company assets: Frequent flyer abuse

sec.p: A company that has many out-of-town clients has negotiated a special rate with airline E—a 35% discount between designated cities—and encourages its employees to use that airline whenever possible. Salesperson T prefers to use Airline D because of their “frequent flier” program (which allows him to earn free personal trips). In some cases, T has booked flights on Airline D even though the tickets cost up to $200 more than similar flights on Airline E, just so T could “rack up those frequent flier points.” T doesn’t use the points for business travel.

list-item.p: 12. Trust: Indiscreet use of information

sec.p: Salesperson B had several customers who were in competition with each other. Sometimes a customer would ask for information about one of the other customers (e.g., “Did they have any special sales coming up?”). To gain favor with one customer, B would sometimes “let something slip” about another customer. B felt that this was acceptable as long as that customer had not explicitly asked him to hold a piece of information in confidence.

list-item.p: 13. Withholding information

sec.p: Salesperson J works for a consumer electronics store. Although Salesperson J always makes the customer aware of all of the features and benefits of a product, the drawbacks, and limitations of the product are rarely, if ever, mentioned.

list-item.p: 14. Defamation: Misrepresentation/down selling of a competitor

sec.p: Salesperson U works for a firm that has been in business for 50 years. Most businesses do not make it to Year 5. When a buyer asks about a competitor who has been in business for 2 years, Salesperson U replies that they will probably be going out of business soon.

list-item.p: 15. Coercion: Tying agreement

sec.p: Salesperson A sells Company C’s products to retailers. Product A is a good product with high demand, but Product B is old and has low demand. When meeting with a retailer, Salesperson A says that the retailer can only have Product A if the retailer also agrees to stock Product B.

list-item.p: 16. Price discrimination: Charging customers different prices based on their negotiation ability

sec.p: Salesperson N sells a product that has a negotiable price. Salesperson N charges a lower price to buyers that have several sources to buy similar product, and charges a higher price to buyers who use Salesperson N’s company as a sole source for the product.

list-item.p: 17. Puffery

sec.p: When customers ask for product specifications, Salesperson U always presents accurate information. To conclude the presentation, Salesperson U usually asserts that the product “can’t be beat.”

list-item.p: 18. Reciprocity

sec.p: Salesperson Y sells advertising space for a local paper. While visiting a local copier distributor, Salesperson Y assures the copier distributor that the paper will renew its copier contract with the distributor if the distributor agrees to a one-year advertising contract.

list-item.p: 19. Special treatment

sec.p: Salesperson E enjoys sports and frequently visits Business R since the buyer at Business R is an avid sports fan. Business R represents 10% of Salesperson E’s revenue, and Salesperson E spends 15% of his time visiting and servicing the Business R account.

list-item.p: 20. Dishonesty: Scarcity (excessively limited choice)

sec.p: Salesperson G works for a retail camera store. When a customer was uncertain about whether to buy a camera, G would say, “Let me go to the stock room and see if we have one.” On returning, Salesperson G would say, “That’s the last one in stock—you should buy it while we still have it.”
